thread.title: Marshawn Lynch teams up with Starbucks to create 'Beast Mode Frappuccino'
thread.title_full: Marshawn Lynch teams up with Starbucks to create 'Beast Mode Frappuccino'

title: Marshawn Lynch teams up with Starbucks to create 'Beast Mode Frappuccino'
text:
Marshawn Lynch teams up with Starbucks to create ‘Beast Mode Frappuccino’ Resize Text By Marissa Payne October 21 at 3:26 PM Follow @marissapayne (Photo courtesy of Starbucks) 
There’s no Skittles in it, but there is “purple berry drizzle” in Seattle Seahawks star Marshawn Lynch’s newly created “Beast Mode Frappuccino.” The running back teamed up with Starbucks to create the caffeinated coffee drink to benefit Lynch’s Fam 1st Family Foundation that promotes literacy and education among underprivileged youth. Starbucks will donate 24 cents, which happens to be Lynch’s number, for every Beast Mode Frappuccino sold until it reaches $100,000, according to a company press release . Even if sales slump, however, Starbucks has agreed to contribute at least $24,000. The NFL star's double mocha Frappuccino has a hint of mint and cream and, of course, protein powder. The beverage is topped with whipped cream and finished with a purple berry drizzle and a sprinkle of matcha. For every Frappuccino sold, Starbucks will donate $0.24 to Fam 1st Family Foundation, according to a Starbucks spokesperson. (Starbucks) 
But how could sales slump when you’re dealing with a delicious masterpiece like this? Along with the purple berry drizzle, which along with matcha rests atop a dollop of whipped cream, the Beast Mode beverage blends espresso, chocolate and mint with a healthy dose of protein powder. (Courtesy of Starbucks) 
“I’d drink this before a workout,” Lynch said. “You could get your buff on with this.” 
The drink won’t be available everywhere, however, but starting Thursday it will go on sale in Washington state and in Oakland, Calif., and be available through the rest of the NFL season. Marissa Payne writes for The Early Lead, a fast-breaking sports blog, where she focuses on what she calls the “cultural anthropological” side of sports, aka “mostly the fun stuff.” She is also an avid WWE fan. sports Success!
